text: Patient: Right. Doctor: If you have only one bathroom you'll just be very diligent you'll get some gloves you wipe down after you use the bathroom with because chemo- Family Member: With what? Doctor: Oh with Lysol Clorox anything over the counter you got the wipes. They all work. Family Member 1: Wipes work? Flush twice? Doctor: Yep flush twice and then with the wipes put them in the garbage, but just keep it separate. Patient: Right. Doctor: You know you have a toddler you don't want to- Family Member 1: Well, can he be around? Doctor: - and they just get into it. Family Member 1: Can he still baby sit for A___ when he’s on this medicine? Because we do split shifts. Doctor: So yeah, so that that's a little bit of the hard part. Not so much for you to her, but for her to you. Because if they're their little ones are germy they're just one giant viral bacterial fest, because that's what they they do and they pick up everything. You would be a bit compromised from that. Family Member 1: Could he wear a mask if he wanted?

text: Family Member: Yes. Doctor: Everybody. Family Member: Not me, but yeah, them. Doctor: Right. Everybody that, so, you have one, it’s, it’s a mutation in the gene. You have two copies of the gene. It’s, you know, so there’s a one and four chance you could pass it on because two copies come from your, their mother, and so, the mother contributes one, you contribute one. Patient: Right. Right. Doctor: There’s a fifty/fifty chance, you could contribute a good one or bad one, so they -- you know – does that make sense? Patient: Right. Yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah I know all of that. Doctor: So -. Family Member: Does insurance do anything with this? I mean, do they consider you a risk? Are you -- Doctor: I don’t know. Um, you, you, they’re going to need to talk with their doctors. I do know that the test we did, I think, allows, if we, a discounted test, I’ll find out --- for family members, um, to test as well. Um, there is just a test for BRCA, and then there’s a, you know, at this point these tests are, cover about thirty different genes. Um. That’s the only one they found. So, for your family, I think it, it requires a discussion about it, and then they should – you know, they need to make a decision if they want to get tested or not. Um. It’s a risk factor for prostate and breast. So, and ovarian, so both sons and daughters, and then, you know, their sons and daughters if they – I would say if they were positive. If they were negative, there’s – you know, your grandkids are – it, it can’t skip over it – so, if your sons or daughter is negative (coughs) Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: Unless their – Family Member: Their husband has it –

text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Well, today, we’ve got to sort of talk about what next. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, I just reviewed, again, all the scans from a month ago or so. So really what we see in you is all of the disease seems to be in the bone. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So you don’t have any really anything in lymph nodes, or liver, or lung, which is, you know, good and bad. Uh, the bad part of it is, you know, it’s hard to kind of get a good sense of how things work in the bone because the scans we do are, uh, mostly telling us new spots in the bone. But they, we can’t really measure things getting bigger or smaller. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So often we think of bone as being, we have this sort of feeling that bone is worse, but mostly because we just have trouble imaging and seeing how it changes. So, uh, but it also affects some of the trials we have because those trials require biopsies of tumor tissue, and it’s really hard to get tumor tissue from the bone. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So it may alter what we can do in terms of trials. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So today, I thought we could talk a little bit about kind of what the standard things are to do next, and then we could talk a little bit about some trials that we have. The typical thing we would do next is either to put you on another hormone- Patient: Um hum.

text: Family Member: Right. Right. Doctor: You give the flu shot. You hope to try to prevent it from getting worse. Family Member: Worse. Um hum. Doctor: So the vaccine therapy wakes up your body’s immune system to try to fight the cancer by itself. Family Member: Um hum. Okay. Doctor: We also have information that at least in the, you know, African American men- Family Member: Right. Doctor: That vaccine therapies tend to work a little better. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So with that, that’s why I think it would be a great next stop to do. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: We would have to get clearance from insurance because it’s about a hundred thousand bucks.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Typically, we don’t use that medicine unless it drops. Huh, over the long haul, you might get, huh, injury to the longest nerves in your body. Those are your fingertips and to your toes. Huh, you get numbness. Huh, so we try to go out as many as ten cycles. Most people notice it by the sixth or seventh. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But I’m going to ask you every time can you zip up your thing? Can you button your pants? Can you button your shirt? If you tell me I can’t, I’m going to stop. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: But if your shirt’s coming in and it’s unbuttoned, even though you tell me you did, I’m not going to believe you. Okay? I have ways to check. Patient: Right. (Laughs) Doctor: Okay? Because I don’t want to go too far with the numbness, huh, if that’s a possibility. Patient: Okay. Doctor: One of the things about the positive thing about the vitamin C is there is some bit of the people get less numbness. Huh, normally after three or four doses of the chemotherapy, huh, we have a sense of whether it’s helping. Your PSA may be lower. Your pain may be better. Huh, huh, those are sort of some of the clues. Okay? Huh, if we feel like it’s, you are getting better, we’re going to keep going as far as ten treatments. Huh, if after three or four doses, your pain’s worse, your PSA is higher, huh, I might even get scans after the fourth cycle to follow your lymph nodes. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Huh, because if your PSA is going up, and your lymph nodes are getting bigger, we’re not going to keep giving you the chemotherapy if it’s causing all those side effects. Patient: Right.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
